In many ways I feel like I'm giving it too high of a score, but Ferris Bueller's Day Off is a movie that has a bunch of moving parts, all of which move pretty much flawlessly, and while none of the characters are the deepest in motion picture history, they all work well in their respective roles.  Mathew Broderick is legitimately excellent as the titular Ferris Bueller, a fun fourth-wall breaking character (almost like a semi-slacker predecessor to Wayne & Garth) who is just barely able to ride the line between being Endearing and being Smug.  A lot of this comes from the fact that, despite there is certainly a mild narcissistic element to Ferris' character, he is also almost obsessed with making those around him happy, and honestly, I think it's this facet to the main character that has given this film its longevity.  The rest of the Cast do well with their respective roles, albeit much of them are toned-down caricatures, however the infinitely-underappreciated Alan Ruck deserves some serious props as well, as his character largely lives in a self-induced misery (caused perhaps by some mild but genuine neuroses), however his story is actually one tinged with a soft, long-lasting sadness due to his parents' (unseen in the movie, a wise choice in my opinion) intense emotional distance from him, as well as from each other.  Alan Ruck's Cameron is, in a sense, the beating-heart of the film, bolstering Ferris' more empathetic side, and this allows the movie to feel a lot more endearing by the end than it otherwise would.  And for that, I do genuinely kinda love this movie -- It's breezy, it's fun, it's never mean-spirited (at least never intensely or for more than a few seconds), and it has a softer side that's genuinely welcome.

Think back to when you were a teenager. Remember the times we all dreaded. In the Film Ferris Bueller's Day Off It follows that exact scenario. The film was directed by John Hughes and released on June 11th, 1986, and it is considered one of the greats in 80s films. 
 
A single aspect in the film that really caught my eye was the acting, the Fourth Wall breaks to be specific. The film is very comedic, and someone can even say the comedic value is on par with Home Alone, but the comedic moments in Ferris Buellers are enhanced with these fourth wall breaks. Ferris who's played by Mathew Broderik is the only character who's able to break the Fourth Wall and he does it quite a lot in the film. The moments when he talks directly to the audience make him look like a cocky teenager who's able to bend the rules of his parents every time, while also giving the audience something to laugh at. 
 
My overall reaction to the film was positive. I saw little to no downsides to the film and experienced nothing, but the dumb fun of a teenager's day off from school. Despite being from the 80s the film's comedy has not aged one bit. I believe anyone with a sense of humor is able to come watch this film and have no trouble having a good laugh. If I had to rate the movie out of 5 stars, I would give it a 4.5. I remember discovering this movie when a colleague had told me to stop being such a Cameron Fry. I didn't know what the heck that meant and eventually found out who he was and watched the movie.

This is the movie where Matthew Broderick famously breaks the fourth wall. Making comments and giving looks directly to the audience. It's a funny gag, there's even an post-credits scene where he approaches the camera asking why the audience is /still/ there and tells them to go home. While I did watch this movie in my house, the line did get a couple chuckles out of me. The premise is incredibly simple: teen gets friends together, skips school, and causes shenanigans throughout the city while a skeptical principal (Jeffrey Jones) pursues him. Oh right! The dynamic between the principal as well as Bueller's sister (played by Dirty Dancing actress Jennifer Grey) and Ferris creates some of the funniest moments. It's a cat and mouse game, like Tom And Jerry, between them and is incredibly entertaining to watch.

Now I know this will sound iffy, but Ferris Bueller is and can be a positive role model, just depends on how you look at it. Yes he cuts school and makes risky decisions throughout, but it's all in good fun. And for those of us like Cameron Fry, sometimes we need to just let loose and have fun every now and again. Like Bueller famously says to the camera: "Life moves pretty fast, if you don't stop and look around once in a while, you could miss it."

A film as beloved as this one has had so much said about it but I think what it comes down to is that this is an extremely entertaining diversion. It is hardly meaningful and it is not the meaningful paean about self discovery that some believe it to be but it features a great soundtrack, a genius central performance and some beautifully choreographed shots. Few films have made a city look as wonderful as this film makes Chicago appear and as they move through all of the famous tourist sites we realize that we are watching a very well packaged, glossy travelogue. All of this makes the film worth watching and when you want to relax and not put yourself through the emotional strain of Ship of Fools (1965) or Room at the Top (1959).

Smug high school student Ferris Bueller, Matthew Broderick, regularly fakes being sick so he can take a day off school and spend his time with his girlfriend Sloane Peterson, Mia Sara, and emotionally traumatized best friend Cameron Frye, Alan Ruck. This angers his sister Jeanie, Jennifer Grey, who does not break the rules like he does and she wants to see him punished for his actions. Bueller maneuvers to get his girlfriend out of school by pretending to be her father and incurs the wrath of school principal Mr. Rooney, Jeffrey Jones, who tries to track him down throughout the day. Bueller has more of a struggle getting Frye to come with him as he is afraid of even leaving his house and as Bueller wants to use his father's Ferrari which he worries his father will learn about it takes a lot of cajoling to get him to tag along with them. They travel through Chicago and enjoy themselves but at the end of the day they are all almost caught out.

The fun of the film comes in seeing a figure, a teenager, who is usually in a position where authority figures like his parents and schoolteachers control him is able to manipulate the system to gain freedom. He is smug and taunts those around him about the way that he has succeeded but at heart he does love his girlfriend and best friend and just wants to show them a good time. This is how most teenagers feel and the idea that you could actually control your own life and have fun doing it is appealing to hormonal, angst filled people. The villains in the film are also appropriately caricatured as his parents are politically conservative pushovers and the school principal is the sort of stickler for the rules that we all dislike. His girlfriend is a little too perfect as she is one of those 
‘cool' girls that male screenwriters love but this is a minor complaint as Hughes has written female characters with far less depth who face even more abusive treatment from the men around them.

The one part of the film that I did not like was the relationship that Frye has with his father and it is implied that he is overbearing and controlling but the film applies too much meaning to the idea of defiance. The climactic scene in which he pushes his father's Ferrari through the glass window and out into a ravine annoyed me as the film presents destroying an object valuable to your parents as the correct response to feelings of anger and resentment towards them. To have had Frye actually talk to his father or properly discuss his feelings about him to set up why he is so angry at him and would go to such lengths to attract his attention. I assume that there were a few extra scenes cut out of the film that would have done more to make this scene more poignant and understandable. I wanted to get into this part of the film as Frye is enigmatic at the beginning of the film and we are invested in his coming out of his shell but when the film tries to develop his backstory it fails to put us in his mindset.

You really will love the experience of watching this film even though it is flawed in developing some of the characters.

Let's be honest . . . who here didn't try to play hooky at least once over the course of their academic career? Ferris Bueller happens to be king of the fake sick day and, using his ninth phony day off this semester, decides to show his hypochondriac friend Cameron and level-headed girlfriend Sloane the time of their lives. From admiring paintings in the Art Institute of Chicago to commandeering a parade float to perform in front of an almost magically absurd crowd - all while bending the laws of coincidence - this will be one day our three teenage heroes never forget.

John Hughes is the ultimate progenitor of exploring teen angst in cinema and "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is just one more in a string of classic comedies (including the oft-overlooked "Sixteen Candles" and the legendary malcontent manifesto "The Breakfast Club") that stood head-and-shoulders above their contemporaries. Hughes was note-perfect at writing incisive dialogue suited to the varied styles of his teenage protagonists while penetrating the very heart of human nature at the same time. It helps that Hughes always had stellar casts to work with.

The fourth-wall-breaking performance of Matthew Broderick is one of the best the Eighties ever saw and Broderick's on screen chemistry with Alan Ruck is convincing enough to make the viewer believe these two have been playing off of each other since kindergarten. Jeffrey Jones is a deliciously devilish amalgamation of high school principles while Jennifer Grey does her part as Bueller's sister who simply wants to escape the shadow of her spotlight-stealing brother and find a little recognition of her own. Even Charlie Sheen is on point doing his best Judd Nelson impersonation. "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" is a great example of the kind of heartwarming mischievousness from a more innocent age that we will probably never witness again on the silver screen.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off (1986) is director John Hughes slacker anthem on the big screen. It's highly relatable to teenagers that just want out of school and to hang out with their friends. Every time I revisit this film, it always provides laughter and enjoyment. It's a blast of fourth wall breaks, Chicago sight seeing, and gallivanting with your pals.

John Hughes wrote and directed this pleasant trip with a nod to films like womanizing romance comedy films like Alfie (1966), which also broke the 4th wall to coming of age risque movies such as Risky Business (1983). It takes the romancing teenager with clever wit and poignant commentary on the social lives of suburban Americans. I found Cameron's monologue about his father's love to be even more biting than ever. Hughes had a knack for realistic dialogue from kids, while always trying to find the humor in odd situations. His direction goes from nice slow panning shots to blistering tracking shots and neat jump cuts between faces. This is Hughes on full steam ahead to nonsense and silly entertainment.

Matthew Broderick was the man after this film. His effortless charm and easy going attitude as Ferris Bueller taught us all to relax and appreciate the finer things in life a bit more. He is cool personified, even while being a truant miscreant of the highest caliber.

His friends Cameron and Sloane are really interesting unto themselves. Alan Ruck is hilarious as the dour and sickly Cameron. His nervous gasps and incessant hollering about his father's demands is so charming and relatable that Ruck may often steal the show from Broderick, especially towards the second half of Ferris Bueller's Day Off. His big monologue ranting about his father's expectations, wishes, and car is something to behold. He demonstrates not only a comedic talent, but convincing dramatic appeal as well.

On the other hand, Mia Sara is pretty generic and dull as Sloane. She is certainly pretty, but seems so lifeless compared to the two main boys. While her acting is flat, Jennifer Grey's is so dynamic! Grey is very funny and sympathetic as Ferris' sister Jean. She gives passionate speeches and underhanded comments throughout that always make me smile. Her indignant moaning about Ferris getting away with everything is so funny to me still.

Even Charlie Sheen makes a cameo in the police station putting on his best James Dean from Rebel Without a Cause to funny results. His snark and causal matter of fact delivery to Grey's character remains as funny and strange as ever.

Lastly, Jeffrey Jones is great as the stuffy principal, chasing down Ferris, with goofy results. While he is over the top, you could argue the whole movie takes on a life of its own with ridiculous bits that you will just have to go along with and believe. It's more about the adventure of spending time with your friends than just buying into the nihilism of caring that Ferris spews at you.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off is one of John Hughes' finest achievements, regardless of how well its themes, cast, and situations have aged. I think this will always be a fun movie despite the campy tone and too silly slap stick bits. It is great for an afternoon watch, so long as you are not rooting for Ferris to fail. Just go along with the ride and you'll have a good time.

Ferris, one of the biggest procrastinators in film history, decides to take a day off from school and suggests/forces his closest friends do the same.  What follows is just about the most ridiculously funny high school films to date.  Pulling your parents leg about being sick is one thing, but convincing the entire city of Chicago that you're nearly on your death bed when you're actually singing Twist and Shout in the middle of a parade?  That's another thing entirely.

Yes, seeing a principle go to the lengths that Ed Rooney does to take Ferris down is a bit silly.  But when you have a talent like Jeffrey Jones to work with, you have to take advantage of all the physical comedy chances you have.  But speaking of talent, no one could have played Ferris better than Matthew Broderick.  If you don't buy into Ferris breaking the fourth wall within the first minute or so of the film, than the entire story won't work.  But with Broderick's charismatic charm, you buy into every second of it.  

It's like a great 90's action film, it doesn't take itself too seriously.  It knows that most parents wouldn't actually buy into Ferris' "sickness", or that he could impersonate a well-known Chicagoan to get into a restaurant, or even lead a parade, but the film exploits every one of these situations.  They take every chance they get in creating a ridiculously humorous moment.  

It's not going to blow your socks away with a realistically dramatic take on high school or real-life problems (though some are certainly touched upon), but it is a timeless tale of procrastination during youth, and the great lengths that one could go to make their day extraordinary.  The imagination is strong here.

Ferris Bueller's Day Off

High school senior Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick) just wants a day off from school and will go to extremes to make that happen.  Ferris is the quintessential popular kid who seems to always get what he wants.  He is hedonistic, charming, smart, and consistently does two things to manipulate others:  first, he tells people what they want to hear, and second, he makes and carries out elaborate plans to trick them.  Ferris begins this day by making his parents believe that he is sick.  This is something to which everyone can relate.  Ferris, however, takes it to the next level by making a contraption that will snore when his bedroom door is opened. This way, if his mom checks on him, she will think he is sound asleep.  This is only one of several schemes that he puts in motion to make others believe he is home sick.  After his family leaves the house he invites some friends to join him.  He convinces his best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck), who is a hypochondriac, to get out of bed and join him for the day.  Ferris then concocts a plan to get his girlfriend Sloane (Mia Sara) out of school.  This is accomplished with a phone call to the school's dean of students claiming there has been a death in her family.  Sloane is a pretty girl that would never miss an opportunity to spend a day away from school with Ferris.  He then convinces Cameron to take Cameron's dad's stunning red Ferrari so they can travel to downtown Chicago in style.

After the three friends arrive in downtown Chicago, they park the precious vehicle in a garage and begin their adventures.  They experience fine dining, professional baseball, and an art museum.  Ferris even sings in a parade.  While all of this is taking place, Ferris's jealous sister Jeanie (Jennifer Grey), who knows that he is faking, is doing whatever it takes to make sure Ferris is caught and exposed as the lying faker that he is.  The dean of students at the school is also onto Ferris and will go to extremes to make sure Ferris gets to enjoy a fifth year of high school.  

This day off from school is not just fun and games.  The audience really gets to see the development of Cameron's character.  He is transformed by the end of the day.  Plus, the movie utilizes a style of acting in which the fourth wall is broken.  In other words, Ferris looks right at the camera and talks directly to the audience.  There is no separation, or wall, between the actor and audience.  This helps you feel like you are friends with Ferris Bueller and that you too are enjoying the day off with him, Cameron and Sloane.

Overall the movie is lighthearted and enjoyable to watch.  As stated by Ferris Bueller himself,  " Life moves pretty fast.  If you don't stop and look around once in awhile, you could miss it."

He is the change character, and the one that many people (like me) can connect with so closely. While I find Ferris' antics silly, and occasionally hilarious, the movie has heart because we see Cameron learning how to grow up. The other character who experiences growth in the film is Jeanie, and her story is also handled brilliantly. I like how Charlie Sheen actually teaches her the pointless nature of jealousy, and simultaneously teaches us as well. I could go on for hours just detailing all the things I love about this movie, because every single scene works for me. It has funny parts, it has dramatic parts, and it has emotional parts. The total package is a movie that I can watch any time and it actually makes me nostalgic for those days. I wonder if the movie would be as engaging for teens of this generation, or if so many of us connect with it merely because it was such a product of the 1980s. I'd recommend it to anyone because I love the movie, but I have a feeling only those of us who saw it when we were in high school will form that same emotional connection.

"Ferris Bueller" has its moments, and most of the best ones are of its own making. The much greater number of moments that don't work are a mix of atonal original content and otiose memes of better films.

Almost immediately, Ferris sets the movie outside the bounds of realism by talking to the camera. The technique suits Matthew Broderick's characteristic sense of detachment from the process of acting, his ability to exist on screen without seeming to even try to act but without seeming at all natural either. The cold eyes and feces-eating grin that accompany his verbal asides, though, give the impression that something more is going on in the film than whimsy. There is a darkness-not exactly a darkness, but a kind of menacing quality to the movie, as though it were a prank, and the audience is forever suspended in the instant of dawning horror and appreciation. It as as if John Hughes and a real-life Ferris Bueller are out joyriding in our cars while we are trying to figure out what we are watching, and realizing that it is both a joke for us and a joke on us.

The laugh-out-loud bits are played fairly straight. Ben Stein's steady drone in front of catatonic students. Charlie Sheen's cameo in which "drugs" is an inevitable but perfectly-timed punchline. The cheery profanity of a seemingly old-fashioned school secretary. A glorious song and dance number in the middle of the movie fills the streets of Chicago with color, and the spectacle seems as rich with directorial intent as it is with pure exuberance. John Hughes' placement of WASP city fathers on one side of the street, the ethnic European element of the city in the center, and the black community on the other side is undoubtedly conscious, and is appropriate for Chicago. There is probably no attempt at a social message here; it is part of the movie's non-judgmental celebration of the Windy City, and to portray the city as integrated would have been false.

A gawking fixation on Chicago adds to the sense that there is a movie going on beneath the movie, because there is no way that a kid like Ferris would choose this itinerary for his dream day. The Sears Tower? It's only for tourists. The Art Institute and its collection of 19th and 20th century masterpieces? Please. A black tie restaurant? I'd expect a real teenager to prefer deep-dish pizza and brats. Maybe the secret to understanding Ferris is that he's having the dream day that adults wish they had had, but only if they had known then what they know now.

But if Ferris is such a figure of fantasy, and so above the movie, why does Hughes burden him and his friends with the serious suburban anxieties that some people decades later derisively dub "affluenza"? Hughes had covered that ground very well in "The Breakfast Club," a film whose kids are much more real. In this movie, with its cultivated sense of superiority and apathy, the periodic downshift produces whiplash and slows the pace to an intolerable crawl. Alan Ruck is a good actor, but his best friend character is designed to be a drag and succeeds at it better than intended. Mia Sara's idealized, sexualized girlfriend character is a drag, too, because she has so much less mold-breaking individuality than Ally Sheedy and Molly Ringwold had brought to their earlier collaborations with John Hughes and Matthew Broderick.

Yet "Ferris Bueller" prefigures 21st-century entertainment in a way that the thoroughly dated brat pack films do not. Its use of antihumor, wherein a joke is held in abeyance for a long time while anticipation builds, and in which the big payoff is often understated, paved the way for postmodern high school comedies like "Napoleon Dynamite." This approach to humor is best exemplified by the additional content that plays during the movie's closing credits. Such stingers are rarely seen before "Ferris Bueller" but became a staple of the genre afterward. Instead of using 80s hits, the movie's musical cues are more timeless, like John Lennon and the theme from "Star Wars." Frequently, though, its pop culture references feel arbitrary and meaningless. Why bring "Alien" or Wayne Newton into this? They're drawn from a hat, like a "Family Guy" joke or an internet gif. Like them, the uneven "Ferris Bueller" is sometimes funny, sometimes obnoxious, and sometimes just puzzling.

I appreciate the irony in the fact that after this film, Matthew Broderick, as far as we knew, was the only one in this film who didn't get a day off, because everyone else in this film seemed to all but fall off the radar, which is surprising, considering the impact that this film had on a lot of young folks. Yeah, nothing says, "coming-of-age film" quite like skipping out on responsibilities, kids. Yeah, an education is pretty important in life, too, although I am all for youths embracing life in all of its glory, especially if their revelatory adventure makes Chicago look a little less scary. People, we all knew that John Hughes loved Chicago, but wow, this is about as much as love letter to Chicago as it is a love letter to youth spirit, which I suppose makes it the definitive John Hughes film. Not unlike youth, you've got to embrace this film while you can, because after this, Hughes took himself a break from coming-of-age films and started making movies about grown-ups and stuff. I can't believe Ferris Bueller went through all of the trouble rebelling against both the fourth wall and grown-ups, only for Hughes to end up rejecting youth films... although, in all fairness, he was 36 at the time of this film's release, and he was getting a little old to understand young people problems of the '80s. Well, at least he had enough of a grip to make a film that can be enjoyed by kids, grown-ups and Barbara Bush alike (Way to stay relevant for the Wellesley College kids, Barb), despite having problems beyond a questionable coming-of-age moral (Forget you, Pink Floyd, the kids do need an education).

Saying hardly anything off the bat, then proceeding to give only so much exposition as it progresses, the film probably doesn't need to say much as an almost inconsequential young adult character piece, but developmental shortcomings make it a little difficult to get invested in, or even buy into characters, only so many of which are morally relatable. Storytelling is sharp enough, and acting is charismatic enough, for the characters to endear pretty thoroughly, although there's something a little sleazy about the most major ones, and that's, maybe not distancing, but a little obnoxious at times, in a manner that would be easier to get past if the characters were more fleshed out or, for that matter, organically juggled. While the film is, on the whole, minimalist as a character-driven affair, it will often bring in some layers to its cast and focus, only to find trouble in keeping up with it all, resulting in a certain focal unevenness which makes it even harder to get invested in the characters. Perhaps the film would be a little more even if it was tighter in its storytelling, being not especially overlong with its 102-minute runtime, but still with certain touches of filler that outstay their welcome and thin already uneven focus, which would, of course, feel tighter if this narrative carried more intrigue to justify its execution's length. There's simply not a whole lot to say with a story like this, and that's fine, considering the entertainment value of the idea's interpretation, yet the inspiration that backs this flick most every step of the way can carry the final product only so far. The film is fun, make no mistake, but it's not much outside of that, and when inspiration fails to meet the ambition which begets too much bloating for consistency in focus and pacing, it's hard to not be reminded of the limited potential here. With all that said, the film entertains pretty thoroughly, so much so that it borders on rewarding, and stands as worthy of certain recognition, even for its story.

No matter how inconsequential, this film's story concept is relatively solid, as far as comedic narratives are concerned, being colorful and even unique as a portrait on youths' somewhat reasonable, if a little convoluted mission to embrace life while there's still plenty of it, even if it's for only one day. This story is both refreshing and relatable, and that's respectable, as John Hughes seems to understand, even as writer, offering snappy, often even, for a young adult film, gutsy dialogue and lively humor, all behind memorable set pieces - such as unique fourth-wall breaks that give you insight into the mind of the titular character - and, of course, memorable characterization that, while focally uneven and sometimes a bit obnoxious in its intentional drawing of flaws, presents generally charming and distinguished characters. If nothing else brings color to the characters, it's the characters' portrayers, with standouts including a Jeffrey Jones who convinces as a clumsily bitter antagonist, and an Alan Ruck who convinces as a self-conscious voice of reason with his own charming faith in fun, while Matthew Broderick, in a breakout performance, truly drives the film with his butter-smooth charisma and slick energy. While his charm doesn't find its share of challenges in this cast of limited star power, but abundant color, Broderick more-or-less carries the film, which also owes much of its liveliness to style, even musical. Flaunting a trio of composers which includes Ira Newborn, Arthur Baker and John Robie, the film's score is diverse, yet consistently stylish and lively, with moments of borderline killer flare that joins a couple fun tunes in the unoriginal soundtrack in drawing you in almost as much as dynamic locations that paint a handsome and immersive portrait on the distinct setting of Chicago. The film even offers a fine deal of style that, quite frankly, perhaps would be as effectively lively if it wasn't so well-orchestrated by Hughes, as director, whose plays on the aforementioned musical and visual style, and even on Paul Hirsch's snappy editing, keep pacing brisk, and whose occasional thoughtful moments ought to immerse you into the thematic depth of this portrait on coming of age and achieving independence. It's hard to fully agree with a lot of the characters' actions, but the overall theme in this coming-of-age flick is surprisingly subtle and worthy, thus giving the film a heart to go with all of the fun that may not exactly be substantial to the point of seeing the final product transcend its natural shortcomings, but certainly make quite the memorable comedy classic.

At the end of the day, the characters are a little underdeveloped, sometimes obnoxious, and occasionally unevenly handled, while storytelling proves to be repetitiously overdrawn enough for you to think about the inconsequentiality of the narrative concept that render the final product kind of underwhelming, but hardly so underwhelming that a unique and thematically worthy story, on the backs of clever scripting, charming performances, sharp style and colorful, when not thoughtful direction, fails to be enough to drive John Hughes' "Ferris Bueller's Day Off" as a classically fun, if near-inconsequential study on embracing life and youth.

John Hughes makes it look easy.  So this is about the classic ne'er-do-well Ferris Bueller (Matthew Broderick), who decides to play hooky from high school and spend a day in the city with his girlfriend and best friend.  This is another one of those spectacularly 80's movies that still holds up.  Throughout the entire film, the sense of fun is never lost at any point, and that has everything to do with the young Broderick.  Everything about his performance is smirking and self-aware; the sheer number of times he breaks the fourth wall to address the audience is only made possible because of his natural charisma (also, this movie has one of the best stingers of all time).  You also have the principal, Ed Rooney (Jeffrey Jones), who plays one of the more underrated movie villains; just because your movie is a comedy doesn't mean you can't have a quality villain, and Ferris Bueller's Day Off never forgets that.  The focus on the movie is always on the best friend Cameron (Alan Ruck), who is an interesting character to watch, because it is never completely clear how much responsibility lies on his shoulders; sometimes, he plays the victim, and sometimes he is the cause of his own demise.  It's always funny to see how pointless high school can sometimes be, and Ferris Bueller serves as a reminder that it is good for your personal mental health to call out for no reason every now and again.

"Ferris Bueller's Day Off" features Matthew Broderick as the titular character Ferris. On a school day where Ferris is supposed to take a test on a subject that frankly he doesn't care at all about he decides to fake an illness and go out and have fun with his girlfriend Sloane Peterson (Mia Sara) and his best friend Cameron Frye (Alan Ruck). The three decide to go out in style by "borrowing" Mr. Frye's prized 1961 Ferrari 250 FT California Spyder convertible an proceed to explore the city, spending their day sightseeing, visiting attractions, spinning circles around the adults that would send them back to school. Meanwhile the school's Dean Edward Rooney (Jeffrey Jones) tries to bust Forrest, as he is determined to expose him as a juvenile delinquent so he can hold him back a year.

There are two kinds of people that will leave the film, the first are the ones that will leave thinking that Ferris actually is just a juvenile delinquent and the second are the ones who will get swept up by the protagonist's charms. It's easy to see why you wouldn't enjoy the movie at first. Why does Ferris get to fool his parents and skip school while everyone else goes to class? Doesn't he know he's making his parents worry? What about the staff who are just trying to do their job? This kid's just trying to get his friends in trouble by stealing the car! someone catch up with this guy before he hurts someone for goodness sake! To those people, I say calm down for a second and really take a look at the movie. Ferris has a point early in the film when he comments on the test he is supposed to take that day. The test is about a subject that will have no bearings on his life whatsoever; it's useless information and even the teachers that are dispensing the lessons have no interest in it so why bother? Instead of staying at his desk all day and simply learning about life outside, Ferris actually goes outside and lives it. An example is at the Art Institute of Chicago where the trio go to admire some of the pieces on display. It's a beautiful sequence where the characters look at paintings and really analyze and appreciate them (it's done through a montage but you can clearly see Cameron inspecting "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte" by Geirges Seurat). Set to the music of The Smiths, it's moving to see because of the combination of subject matter, music and cinematography. Sure the group get into a couple of situations where they trick adults but for the most part they're not causing any trouble at all. The reason why you're put off by Ferris' behaviour at first is because none of us were that cool. No one dared to skip school so they could go on an adventure and see everything there was to see out there. None of us had the beautiful and dedicated boyfriend/girlfriend that was ready to drop everything and go off on a crazy notion that we had, none of us had the guts to laugh at the authorities and not get caught. You're jealous of the guy but once you learn to just accept that and go along for the ride as his friend Cameron does, it's a heck of a lot of fun.

The film is extremely well written, with many quotable lines and memorable moments. This movie is so iconic that you've seen it parodied at least a dozen times and probably never even knew. Ever seen a movie where there's a car flying over a jump in slow motion? Ever seen a character fail miserably at something and have a musical note laugh at them, "sad tuba" style? Or even more iconic, ever hear that porno-sounding track "Oh Yeah" by Yello, while something awesome is going on? Check this movie out. You'll notice the scene where the Frye's car is flying and the scene where Dean Rooney gets busted at the arcade just as the game of Pacman next to him ends (with the iconic death rattle playing as he realizes how badly he's screwed up). As for the song with Yello, well you'll just have to see for yourself. The characters are iconic and you'll relate to them very well, be it because you want to be like Ferris or because you're seeing a part of yourself in the other characters around him. As the movie progresses his friends and his sisters get a new take on life and while you're sitting there appreciating the movie, you will too. I'm making it sound like the movie is very deep and thought provoking but really that material is a subtext in a very funny and lighthearted film. It's filled with clever one-liners, close calls and smart commentary on the way life treats teenagers. It's a treat to listen to.

There are a few moments of bad over-acting and at least one scene where the movie goes a bit too much into fantasy land but you won't really mind. Even if at first you didn't care for the film, give it another shot and particularly, pay attention to the scene where Jennifer Grey (playing Jeanie, Ferris' sister) is stuck at the police station. There's a nice exchange of dialogue there that will really turn you around on the whole "juvenile delinquent" thing and it's such a crowd pleaser that the material is sure to grow on you. If you haven't seen it, you're missing out and if you have the opportunity to see it for the first time when you're still in school it will really resonate with you. I can't recommend it highly enough. (Theatrical version on the big screen, August 13, 2013)

"Bueller?  Bueller?  Bueller?"  From writer/director John Hughes comes one of the most iconic films of the '80s, Ferris Bueller's Day Off.  The story follows high school senior Ferris Bueller, who ditches school in order to have a day of adventure and wild hijinks.  Starring Matthew Broderick, Mia Sara, Alan Ruck, and Jennifer Grey, the film has a great cast; Broderick in particular has a lot of charisma.  And the comedy is especially well-written; with some very clever meda humor.  Entertaining and incredibly fun, Ferris Bueller's Day Off is an excellent comedy and one of John Hughes' best films.
